docs.snippet: SOMETIMES playing a comic-book hero gives actors a chance to show suave, stylized moves. After stripping off their civvies, they emerge from the phone booth a star. Christopher Reeve gave a breezy, farcical charge to Superman and Clark Kent. As Ba...
docs.lead_paragraph: SOMETIMES playing a comic-book hero gives actors a chance to show suave, stylized moves. After stripping off their civvies, they emerge from the phone booth a star. Christopher Reeve gave a breezy, farcical charge to Superman and Clark Kent. As Batman and his alter ego, the wastrel playboy Bruce Wayne, Michael Keaton seemed to have a thousand things on his mind, most of them unpleasant. Hugh Jackman, Wolverine of ''X-Men,'' had a combative, compulsive snarl. He came to life when prodded to fight. But poor Ben Affleck is lost in the minor, passable ''Daredevil,'' where he portrays the blind, red-costumed and horn-headed crime fighter whose other senses -- hearing, touch, taste -- were exaggerated in the chemical accident that cost him his sight.
docs.abstract: Elvis Mitchell reviews movie Daredevil, written and directed by Mark Steven Johnson, based on Marvel Comics character; Ben Affleck stars; photos (M)

headline.main: Blind Lawyer As Hero In Red

docs.snippet: OLIVIA GOLDSMITH vividly recalls the moment she came to terms with the disintegration of her marriage: it was during a winter's walk 12 years ago along East 77th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues.    ''I come from a nice middle-class fami...
docs.lead_paragraph: OLIVIA GOLDSMITH vividly recalls the moment she came to terms with the disintegration of her marriage: it was during a winter's walk 12 years ago along East 77th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues. ''I come from a nice middle-class family where you don't get a divorce,'' says Ms. Goldsmith, the author of ''The First Wives Club,'' the best seller that is now a hit movie. ''But the next thought I had -- honestly -- I remember looking at the dirty piles of snow, thinking: 'Thank God I have my own money.' ''
docs.abstract: Interview with Olivia Goldsmith on her conservative strategy for investing proceeds of her popular novels, including The First Wives Club; photos; graph (L)ï

headline.main: Once Burned, The First Wife Is Twice Shy

docs.snippet: It takes a daredevil author like Ian Rankin to switch focus from the hero of a series to a villain of the opposite sex. Also: Robert B. Parker and Alexander McCall Smith....
docs.lead_paragraph: Whenever authors of crime fiction feel like taking a break from the old grind, they usually put on a smiley face -- a children's book from Tony Hillerman, a cookbook from Robert B. Parker, a collection of cozy Christmas stories from Mary Higgins Clark. Some find riskier ways of taking a stretch, from writing out of genre to starting a new series, but only a real daredevil would chance switching focus from a popular series sleuth to a character of the opposite sex. Ian Rankin doesn't exactly forfeit his hard-boiled cred with WITCH HUNT (Little, Brown, $19.95), but his bizarre portrait of a female assassin would surely have the manly cops in his grimly realistic Edinburgh police procedurals scratching their heads. ''Witch'' is the code name for the tall, wraithlike woman who has been working as a contract killer for almost 20 years, picking off prominent political, military and industrial figures. Her devious methods and inventive disguises have allowed this lone-wolf predator to go undetected by international law enforcement, until her uncharacteristically violent Channel crossing from Calais to Folkestone alerts agents in the Special Branch and the Secret Service to a possible terrorist attack on the heads of state at a nine-nation summit in London.
docs.abstract: Marilyn Stasio reviews books Witch Hunt by Ian Rankin, Melancholy Baby by Robert B Parker and The Sunday Philosophy Club by Alexander McCall Smith; photo (M)
